trans-unit.source: Consume a Machine Learning web service | Microsoft Azure
trans-unit.target: Consume a Machine Learning web service | Microsoft Azure

trans-unit.source: Once a machine learning service is deployed, the RESTFul web service that is made available can be consumed either as request-response service or as a batch execution service.
trans-unit.target: Once a machine learning service is deployed, the RESTFul web service that is made available can be consumed either as request-response service or as a batch execution service.

trans-unit.source: How to consume an Azure Machine Learning web service that has been deployed from a Machine Learning experiment
trans-unit.target: How to consume an Azure Machine Learning web service that has been deployed from a Machine Learning experiment

trans-unit.source: Introduction
trans-unit.target: Introduction

trans-unit.source: When deployed as a web service, Azure Machine Learning experiments provide a REST API that can be consumed by a wide range of devices and platforms.
trans-unit.target: When deployed as a web service, Azure Machine Learning experiments provide a REST API that can be consumed by a wide range of devices and platforms.

trans-unit.source: This is because the simple REST API accepts and responds with JSON formatted messages.
trans-unit.target: This is because the simple REST API accepts and responds with JSON formatted messages.

trans-unit.source: The Azure Machine Learning portal provides code that can be used to call the web service in R, C#, and Python.
trans-unit.target: The Azure Machine Learning portal provides code that can be used to call the web service in R, C#, and Python.

trans-unit.source: But these services can be called with any programming language and from any device that satisfies three criteria:
trans-unit.target: But these services can be called with any programming language and from any device that satisfies three criteria:

trans-unit.source: Has a network connection
trans-unit.target: Has a network connection

trans-unit.source: Has SSL capabilities to perform HTTPS requests
trans-unit.target: Has SSL capabilities to perform HTTPS requests

trans-unit.source: Has the ability to parse JSON (by hand or support libraries)
trans-unit.target: Has the ability to parse JSON (by hand or support libraries)

trans-unit.source: This means the services can be consumed from web applications, mobile applications, custom desktop applications and even from within Excel.
trans-unit.target: This means the services can be consumed from web applications, mobile applications, custom desktop applications and even from within Excel.

trans-unit.source: An Azure Machine Learning web service can be consumed in two different ways, either as a request-response service or as a batch execution service.
trans-unit.target: An Azure Machine Learning web service can be consumed in two different ways, either as a request-response service or as a batch execution service.

trans-unit.source: In each scenario the functionality is provided through the RESTFul web service that is made available for consumption once the experiment has been deployed.
trans-unit.target: In each scenario the functionality is provided through the RESTFul web service that is made available for consumption once the experiment has been deployed.

trans-unit.source: Deploying a Machine Learning web service in Azure with an Azure web service end-point, where the service is automatically scaled based on usage, you can avoid upfront and ongoing costs for hardware resources.
trans-unit.target: Deploying a Machine Learning web service in Azure with an Azure web service end-point, where the service is automatically scaled based on usage, you can avoid upfront and ongoing costs for hardware resources.

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.TIP] For a simple way to create a web app to access your predictive web service, see [Consume an Azure Machine Learning web service with a web app template](machine-learning-consume-web-service-with-web-app-template.md).
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.TIP] For a simple way to create a web app to access your predictive web service, see [Consume an Azure Machine Learning web service with a web app template](machine-learning-consume-web-service-with-web-app-template.md).

trans-unit.source: For information about how to create and deploy an Azure Machine Learning web service, see [Deploy an Azure Machine Learning web service][publish].
trans-unit.target: For information about how to create and deploy an Azure Machine Learning web service, see [Deploy an Azure Machine Learning web service][publish].

trans-unit.source: For a step-by-step walkthrough of creating a Machine Learning experiment and deploying it, see [Develop a predictive solution by using Azure Machine Learning][walkthrough].
trans-unit.target: For a step-by-step walkthrough of creating a Machine Learning experiment and deploying it, see [Develop a predictive solution by using Azure Machine Learning][walkthrough].

trans-unit.source: Request-Response Service (RRS)
trans-unit.target: Request-Response Service (RRS)

trans-unit.source: A Request-Response Service (RRS) is a low-latency, highly scalable web service used to provide an interface to the stateless models that have been created and deployed from an Azure Machine Learning Studio experiment.
trans-unit.target: A Request-Response Service (RRS) is a low-latency, highly scalable web service used to provide an interface to the stateless models that have been created and deployed from an Azure Machine Learning Studio experiment.

trans-unit.source: It enables scenarios where the consuming application expects a response in real-time.
trans-unit.target: It enables scenarios where the consuming application expects a response in real-time.

trans-unit.source: RRS accepts a single row, or multiple rows, of input parameters and can generate a single row, or multiple rows, as output.
trans-unit.target: RRS accepts a single row, or multiple rows, of input parameters and can generate a single row, or multiple rows, as output.

trans-unit.source: The output row(s) can contain multiple columns.
trans-unit.target: The output row(s) can contain multiple columns.

trans-unit.source: An example for RRS is validating the authenticity of an application.
trans-unit.target: An example for RRS is validating the authenticity of an application.

trans-unit.source: Hundreds to millions of installations of an application can be expected in this case.
trans-unit.target: Hundreds to millions of installations of an application can be expected in this case.

trans-unit.source: When the application starts up, it makes a call to the RRS service with the relevant input.
trans-unit.target: When the application starts up, it makes a call to the RRS service with the relevant input.

trans-unit.source: The application then receives a validation response from the service that either allows or blocks the application from performing.
trans-unit.target: The application then receives a validation response from the service that either allows or blocks the application from performing.

trans-unit.source: Batch Execution Service (BES)
trans-unit.target: Batch Execution Service (BES)

trans-unit.source: A Batch Execution Service (BES) is a service that handles high volume, asynchronous, scoring of a batch of data records.
trans-unit.target: A Batch Execution Service (BES) is a service that handles high volume, asynchronous, scoring of a batch of data records.

trans-unit.source: The input for the BES contains a batch of records from a variety of sources, such as blobs, tables in Azure, SQL Azure, HDInsight (results of a Hive Query, for example), and HTTP sources.
trans-unit.target: The input for the BES contains a batch of records from a variety of sources, such as blobs, tables in Azure, SQL Azure, HDInsight (results of a Hive Query, for example), and HTTP sources.

trans-unit.source: The output for the BES contains the results of the scoring.
trans-unit.target: The output for the BES contains the results of the scoring.

trans-unit.source: Results are output to a file in Azure blob storage and data from the storage endpoint is returned in the response.
trans-unit.target: Results are output to a file in Azure blob storage and data from the storage endpoint is returned in the response.

trans-unit.source: A BES would be useful when responses are not needed immediately, such as for regularly scheduled scoring for individuals or internet of things (IOT) devices.
trans-unit.target: A BES would be useful when responses are not needed immediately, such as for regularly scheduled scoring for individuals or internet of things (IOT) devices.

trans-unit.source: Examples
trans-unit.target: Examples

trans-unit.source: To show how both RRS and BES work, we use an example Azure web service.
trans-unit.target: To show how both RRS and BES work, we use an example Azure web service.

trans-unit.source: This service would be used in an IOT (Internet Of Things) scenario.
trans-unit.target: This service would be used in an IOT (Internet Of Things) scenario.

trans-unit.source: To keep it simple, our device only sends up one value, `cog_speed`, and gets a single answer back.
trans-unit.target: To keep it simple, our device only sends up one value, `cog_speed`, and gets a single answer back.

trans-unit.source: There are four pieces of information that are needed to call either the RRS or BES service.
trans-unit.target: There are four pieces of information that are needed to call either the RRS or BES service.

trans-unit.source: This information is readily available from the service pages in [Azure Machine Learning Studio](https://studio.azureml.net) once the experiment has been deployed.
trans-unit.target: This information is readily available from the service pages in [Azure Machine Learning Studio](https://studio.azureml.net) once the experiment has been deployed.

trans-unit.source: Click on the WEB SERVICES tab at the left of the screen and you will see the deployed services.
trans-unit.target: Click on the WEB SERVICES tab at the left of the screen and you will see the deployed services.

trans-unit.source: Click a service to find the following links and information for both RRS and BES:
trans-unit.target: Click a service to find the following links and information for both RRS and BES:

trans-unit.source: The service **API key**, available on the services Dashboard
trans-unit.target: The service **API key**, available on the services Dashboard

trans-unit.source: The service **request URI**, available on the API help page for the chosen service
trans-unit.target: The service **request URI**, available on the API help page for the chosen service

trans-unit.source: The expected API **request headers** and **body**, available on the API help page for the chosen service
trans-unit.target: The expected API **request headers** and **body**, available on the API help page for the chosen service

trans-unit.source: The expected API **response headers** and **body**, available on the API help page for the chosen service
trans-unit.target: The expected API **response headers** and **body**, available on the API help page for the chosen service

trans-unit.target: In the two examples below, the C# language is used to illustrate the code needed and the targeted platform is a Windows 8 desktop.

trans-unit.target: Click **REQUEST/RESPONSE** under **API HELP PAGE** on the service Dashboard to view the API help page.

trans-unit.target: On this page, aside from the URI, you will find input and output definitions and code samples.

trans-unit.source: BES Example
trans-unit.target: BES Example

trans-unit.source: Unlike the RRS service, the BES service is asynchronous.
trans-unit.target: Unlike the RRS service, the BES service is asynchronous.

trans-unit.source: This means that the BES API is simply queuing up a job to be executed, and the caller polls the job's status to see when it has completed.
trans-unit.target: This means that the BES API is simply queuing up a job to be executed, and the caller polls the job's status to see when it has completed.

trans-unit.source: Here are the operations currently supported for batch jobs:
trans-unit.target: Here are the operations currently supported for batch jobs:

trans-unit.source: Create (submit) a batch job
trans-unit.target: Create (submit) a batch job

trans-unit.source: Start this batch job
trans-unit.target: Start this batch job

trans-unit.source: Get the status or result of the batch job
trans-unit.target: Get the status or result of the batch job

trans-unit.source: Cancel a running batch job
trans-unit.target: Cancel a running batch job

trans-unit.source: **1. Create a Batch Execution Job**
trans-unit.target: **1. Create a Batch Execution Job**

trans-unit.source: When creating a batch job for your Azure Machine Learning service endpoint, you can specify several parameters that will define this batch execution:
trans-unit.target: When creating a batch job for your Azure Machine Learning service endpoint, you can specify several parameters that will define this batch execution:

trans-unit.source: **Input**: represents a blob reference where the batch job's input is stored.
trans-unit.target: **Input**: represents a blob reference where the batch job's input is stored.

trans-unit.source: **GlobalParameters**: represents the set of global parameters you can define for their experiment.
trans-unit.target: **GlobalParameters**: represents the set of global parameters you can define for their experiment.

trans-unit.source: An Azure Machine Learning experiment can have both required and optional parameters that customize the service's execution, and the caller is expected to provide all required parameters, if applicable.
trans-unit.target: An Azure Machine Learning experiment can have both required and optional parameters that customize the service's execution, and the caller is expected to provide all required parameters, if applicable.

trans-unit.source: These parameters are specified as a collection of key-value pairs.
trans-unit.target: These parameters are specified as a collection of key-value pairs.

trans-unit.source: **Outputs**: if the service has defined one or more outputs, the caller can redirect any of them to an Azure blob location.
trans-unit.target: **Outputs**: if the service has defined one or more outputs, the caller can redirect any of them to an Azure blob location.

trans-unit.source: This allows you to save the service's output(s) in a preferred location and under a predictable name, otherwise the output blob name is randomly generated.
trans-unit.target: This allows you to save the service's output(s) in a preferred location and under a predictable name, otherwise the output blob name is randomly generated.

trans-unit.source: Note that the service expects the output content, based on its type, to be saved as supported formats:
trans-unit.target: Note that the service expects the output content, based on its type, to be saved as supported formats:

trans-unit.source: dataset outputs: can be saved as **.csv, .tsv, .arff**
trans-unit.target: dataset outputs: can be saved as **.csv, .tsv, .arff**

trans-unit.source: trained model outputs: can be saved as **.ilearner**
trans-unit.target: trained model outputs: can be saved as **.ilearner**

trans-unit.source: Output location overrides are specified as a collection of *<output name, blob reference>* pairs, where the *output name* is the user defined name for a specific output node (also shown on the service's API help page), and *blob reference* is a reference to an Azure blob location to which the output is to be redirected.
trans-unit.target: Output location overrides are specified as a collection of *<output name, blob reference>* pairs, where the *output name* is the user defined name for a specific output node (also shown on the service's API help page), and *blob reference* is a reference to an Azure blob location to which the output is to be redirected.

trans-unit.source: All these job creation parameters can be optional depending on the nature of your service.
trans-unit.target: All these job creation parameters can be optional depending on the nature of your service.

trans-unit.source: For example, services with no input node defined do not require passing in an *Input* parameter.
trans-unit.target: For example, services with no input node defined do not require passing in an *Input* parameter.

trans-unit.source: Likewise, the output location override feature is completely optional, as outputs will otherwise be stored in the default storage account that was set up for your Azure Machine Learning workspace.
trans-unit.target: Likewise, the output location override feature is completely optional, as outputs will otherwise be stored in the default storage account that was set up for your Azure Machine Learning workspace.

trans-unit.source: Below, we show a sample request payload, as passed to the REST API, for a service where only the input information is provided:
trans-unit.target: Below, we show a sample request payload, as passed to the REST API, for a service where only the input information is provided:

trans-unit.source: **Sample Request**
trans-unit.target: **Sample Request**

trans-unit.source: The response to the batch job creation API is the unique job ID that was associated to your job.
trans-unit.target: The response to the batch job creation API is the unique job ID that was associated to your job.

trans-unit.source: This ID is very important because it provides the only means for you to reference this job in the system for other operations.
trans-unit.target: This ID is very important because it provides the only means for you to reference this job in the system for other operations.

trans-unit.source: **Sample Response**
trans-unit.target: **Sample Response**

trans-unit.source: **2. Start a Batch Execution Job**
trans-unit.target: **2. Start a Batch Execution Job**

trans-unit.source: Creating a batch job registers it within the system and places it in a *Not started* state.
trans-unit.target: Creating a batch job registers it within the system and places it in a *Not started* state.

trans-unit.source: To actually schedule the job for execution, you call the **start** API described on the service endpoint's API help page and provide the job ID obtained when the job was created.
trans-unit.target: To actually schedule the job for execution, you call the **start** API described on the service endpoint's API help page and provide the job ID obtained when the job was created.

trans-unit.source: **3. Get the Status of a Batch Execution Job**
trans-unit.target: **3. Get the Status of a Batch Execution Job**

trans-unit.source: You can poll the status of your asynchronous batch job at any time by passing the job's ID to the GetJobStatus API.
trans-unit.target: You can poll the status of your asynchronous batch job at any time by passing the job's ID to the GetJobStatus API.

trans-unit.source: The API response will contain an indicator of the job's current state, as well as the actual results of the batch job if it has completed successfully.
trans-unit.target: The API response will contain an indicator of the job's current state, as well as the actual results of the batch job if it has completed successfully.

trans-unit.source: In the case of an error, more information about the actual reasons behind the failure are returned in the *Details* property, as shown here:
trans-unit.target: In the case of an error, more information about the actual reasons behind the failure are returned in the *Details* property, as shown here:

trans-unit.source: **Response Payload**
trans-unit.target: **Response Payload**

trans-unit.source: *StatusCode* can be one of the following:
trans-unit.target: *StatusCode* can be one of the following:

trans-unit.source: Not started
trans-unit.target: Not started

trans-unit.source: Running
trans-unit.target: Running

trans-unit.source: Failed
trans-unit.target: Failed

trans-unit.source: Cancelled
trans-unit.target: Cancelled

trans-unit.source: Finished
trans-unit.target: Finished

trans-unit.source: The *Results* property is populated only if the job has completed successfully (it is **null** otherwise).
trans-unit.target: The *Results* property is populated only if the job has completed successfully (it is **null** otherwise).

trans-unit.source: Upon the job has completed, and if the service has at least one output node defined, the results will be returned as a collection of *[output name, blob reference]* pairs, where the blob reference is a SAS read-only reference to the blob containing the actual result.
trans-unit.target: Upon the job has completed, and if the service has at least one output node defined, the results will be returned as a collection of *[output name, blob reference]* pairs, where the blob reference is a SAS read-only reference to the blob containing the actual result.

trans-unit.source: **Sample Response**
trans-unit.target: **Sample Response**

trans-unit.source: **4. Cancel a Batch Execution Job**
trans-unit.target: **4. Cancel a Batch Execution Job**

trans-unit.source: A running batch job can be cancelled at any time by calling the designated CancelJob API and passing in the job's id.
trans-unit.target: A running batch job can be cancelled at any time by calling the designated CancelJob API and passing in the job's id.

trans-unit.source: This would be done for various reasons such as that the job is taking too long to complete.
trans-unit.target: This would be done for various reasons such as that the job is taking too long to complete.

trans-unit.source: Using the BES SDK
trans-unit.target: Using the BES SDK

trans-unit.source: The [BES SDK Nugget package](http://www.nuget.org/packages/Microsoft.Azure.MachineLearning/) provides functions that simplify calling BES to score in batch mode.
trans-unit.target: The [BES SDK Nugget package](http://www.nuget.org/packages/Microsoft.Azure.MachineLearning/) provides functions that simplify calling BES to score in batch mode.

trans-unit.source: To install the Nuget package, in Visual Studio in the **Tools** menu, select **Nuget Package Manager** and click **Package Manager Console**.
trans-unit.target: To install the Nuget package, in Visual Studio in the **Tools** menu, select **Nuget Package Manager** and click **Package Manager Console**.

trans-unit.source: Azure Machine Learning experiments that are deployed as web services can include web service input modules.
trans-unit.target: Azure Machine Learning experiments that are deployed as web services can include web service input modules.

trans-unit.source: This means that they expect the input to be provided through the web service call in the form of a reference to a blob location.
trans-unit.target: This means that they expect the input to be provided through the web service call in the form of a reference to a blob location.

trans-unit.source: There is also the option of not using a web service input module and using a **Reader** module instead.
trans-unit.target: There is also the option of not using a web service input module and using a **Reader** module instead.

trans-unit.source: In this case, the **Reader** module typically would read from a SQL DB using a query at run time to get the data.
trans-unit.target: In this case, the **Reader** module typically would read from a SQL DB using a query at run time to get the data.

trans-unit.source: Web service parameters can be used to dynamically point to other servers or tables, etc. The SDK supports both of these patterns.
trans-unit.target: Web service parameters can be used to dynamically point to other servers or tables, etc. The SDK supports both of these patterns.

trans-unit.target: The code sample below demonstrates how you can submit and monitor a batch job against an Azure Machine Learning service endpoint using the BES SDK.
